bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos E. Finlay, November 22, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Carlos E. Finlay a reprint of his yellow fever article, and hopes that Finlay regards it as the beginning of a campaign to publicize the work of Finlay's father, Carlos J. Finlay, in America. He discusses his continuing efforts to create a memorial to the yellow fever work at the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos E. Finlay, November 22, 1941
div1.opener:
November 22, 1941
Dr. C. E. Finlay
Linea Numero 710
Vedado, Habana
Cuba
My dear Doctor Finlay:
div1.p:
Permit me to send you by separate post a reprint of an address I gave in
June at the unveiling of Cornwell's painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.” In my
address I could only give a rapid sketch of the many events which led up to the
conquest and could of course only touch briefly on the wonderful contributions of
your distinguished father. But I hope that you will see in the painting and in
my brief remarks a sincere attempt to make at least the first steps in the di-
rection of acquainting more fully the American public and medical profession of
this generation with the tremendous importance of your father's work. I intend
to keep on with my investigations so that I may write a full and unbiased account
of the conquest sometime in the future.

Meanwhile I am continuing my efforts to raise money to purchase the
site or the San Jose farm made doubly historical by the early work of your
father there and the later work of the U. S. Army Commission. I will let you
know how our plans progress. I am corresponding with the present owner of the
site to see what can be done to purchase it and to erect here or elsewhere a
suitable building in which to house important relics of the work of your father
and the Reed board. It gives me much pleasure to think that I can help in a
small way to bring into closer comradeship and understanding the medical pro-
fessions of our two republics.

closer.seg:
P. S. Should you wish more of these reprints I should be delighted
to send you all you want. I have a generous supply.
